https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-11-14/secret-ships-boost-venezuelan-oil-exports-despite-u-s-sanctions The Dragon, a massive oil tanker flying the Liberian flag, is supposed to be floating somewhere off the coast of France, according to its last GPS signal. Instead, it’s currently thousands of miles away in Venezuela where, under contract for the Russian state-oil giant Rosneft Oil Co PJSC, it loaded 2 million barrels of oil, according to data compiled by Bloomberg and shipping reports. How’s that possible? Because the ship’s transponders were turned off before it slipped into Venezuelan waters, the data shows. The practice of oil tankers turning off their location signals has increased in the past month, according to shipping data, after the U.S. went after a Chinese-owned shipping company it said was moving crude for sanctioned Iran. The U.S. is seeking to squeeze the Nicolas Maduro government in Venezuela by starving it of oil revenue. But more and more tankers appear to be using the technique to avoid penalties, helping give a boost to Venezuelan crude output that has plummeted since the U.S. imposed sanctions. Venezuela loaded 10.86 million barrels of crude oil in the first 11 days of November, more than double the volume in the same period last month. About half of those barrels were loaded onto ships that had turned off their transponders, which later delivered cargoes to China and India, data compiled by Bloomberg show.
https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/venezuela-is-secretly-exporting-millions-of-barrels-of-oil-1.1348001 In terms of recent shipments and their destination, data by IHS Markit Commodities at Sea suggests that activity observed so far this month (excluding ships not sending any signals) has declined further, with liftings not surpassing 400,000 b/d. India and China continue absorbing most of these volumes, with a marginal increase to report on flows to Europe (if currently reported destination proves accurate). I am combining the inside and outside view for this answer. After reading about the situation in Venezuela, the point is that Maduro still has all he needs for keeping himself in power. Right now the deal seems to be exporting gold, and it's unlikely that this will change in the next two to three months. I use this to justify that him staying in power for so long is not mere chance, but the most probable outcome (80% of more). Guaido has been acting president for about nine months. If I assume a fixed probability "x" of Maduro ceasing to be president for each month, then I notice that (1-x)^9 ~ 0.8 for x = 0.025 (or 2.5% per month). So if Maduro being still president of Venezuela is the expected outcome from the fact that he keeps control of the army (and his parallel police and intelligence offices), he keeps getting money from drug trafficking and exporting gold and he still has the support of Cuba, Turkey, China and Russia, then at most his probability of not holding to power is 2.5% per month. There are 2.5 months to go, so we end up with a probability in between 0 and 6%, with a mean of 3%, which is what I will take as the answer.

Just a bloody nose could cause poorly-led and poorly motivated VZ troops to collapse and to rush in disorder back  to the cities.

PDVSA and China’s state-run CNPC have stopped all oil blending at their joint venture operation, Petrosinovensa, exclusive Reuters sources divulged on Thursday. PDVSA holds 50.1% of the JV, while CNPC holds the remaining 49.9%. PetroSinovensa blended extra-heavy crude oil from Venezuela’s Orinoco belt with lighter grades such as Mesa and Santa Barbara, creating what is known as the Merey blend, 100% of which were shipped to China, Argus Media reported over the summer. Over half of the finished product went toward paying back loans that China extended to Venezuela and PDVSA. The oil blending operations were halted this week due to an untenable buildup in oil stocks in Venezuela as the United States continues to clamp down on the Maduro regime in the Latin country, in what will surely create a ripple effect on other operations in Venezuela as well. The operations at Petrosinovensa was until now the last man standing, as the country’s other oil blending joint venture, Petropiar, already stopped its blending operations earlier this year, also under the weight of growing oil product inventories. https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/Venezuela-Halts-Last-Oil-Blending-Operation.html

On Tuesday I published commentary on the implications of the TIAR for paying subscribers. I’ve dropped the paywall on it and everyone can access the report here. Since I wrote that report, Maduro and his entourage have had their meeting in Russia with Vladimir Putin. They received a shipment of flu vaccines and promises to maintain weapons systems sold by Russia, but no new deals on oil or humanitarian aid that the government had hoped to obtain. In a blow to the hardliners in Maduro’s circle, Putin acknowledged the legitimacy of the Guaido-led National Assembly and recommended Maduro return to the Norway-mediated negotiations process. A large number of Maduro regime officials traveled outside the country simultaneously during the de facto president’s trip to Russia. Diosdado Cabello made a public visit to North Korea. Tareck el-Aissami was out of the country. Delcy and Jorge Rodriguez appeared to leave for New York City for the UNGA. While there was significant speculation about why all the individuals traveled at the same time, sources in Venezuela could not provide any concrete reasons for the sudden surge in travel. A large number of flights from Russia have landed in Venezuela over the past 7-10 days. There have been few public announcements about what sort of equipment or personnel is being shipped in or how many tons of gold have been shipped out. Russia has said there are personnel in the country to repair military equipment. A number of PSUV legislators rejoined the National Assembly. They were given time to speak and nearly all made a case for the legislature to work to reverse the sanctions by the US and other countries against Venezuela and officials in the Maduro regime.  Their speeches did not do much. The Trump administration banned a large number of the regime - including members of the ANC, high ranking military officers, and their families - from traveling to the US. The EU placed new sanctions on seven individuals accused of torture and human rights abuses.

https://boz.substack.com  Venezuela update: Negotiations, false negotiations, power politics, and oil prices Juan Guaido announced the Barbados negotiations process is over after Maduro’s side refused to show up for multiple weeks. Guaido told the media that he offered to step down if Maduro did the same, creating the potential for a transition government that included military representation. By making the offer public, Guaido extended an olive branch to the military and demonstrated that they may be able to get a better deal with Maduro out of power.  Maduro’s FARC troubles: Maduro appears to be flustered by the ongoing narrative regarding the ELN and FARC presence in Venezuela and the recent acceleration of the debate over the implementation of the Rio Treaty (TIAR). Maduro’s concerns about being blamed for harboring terrorists add to the significant impact sanctions are having on his stability. Maduro tried to distract with an over-the-top response of military exercises near the border. He tried to change the subject by pointing to two photos of Guaido with Rastrojos leaders who were also taking refuge in Venezuela. Neither of those moves appear to have changed to focus for the hemisphere, which will discuss the issue under the framework of the TIAR next week. False negotiations: Maduro’s reopening negotiations with a small branch of the opposition who disagree with Guaido’s strategy and the recent release of political prisoners appear aimed to gain his side some good will going into the UN General Assembly meetings. However, sources told Hxagon that Maduro’s move to open negotiations with a false opposition branch may have done more to divide his own coalition than Guaido’s. Diosdado Cabello is unhappy with the new negotiation process because he views it as eventually limiting the power of the National Constituent Assembly (ANC) that he runs. Elements within the military view the false negotiation as a waste of time failing to address the key stability issues the country faces. From inside the regime, the big winners in this false negotiation process appear to be the Rodriguez siblings, with Vice President Delcy Rodriguez and Minister of Information Jorge Rodriguez being the public faces of the new process. The fight over the National Assembly: The negotiations with small parties are a concern for Guaido as the PSUV has said they will rejoin the National Assembly (AN). There is a possibility that the government will attempt to toss out Guaido from within. While Guaido’s coalition has a large majority of the seats and recently voted to renew Guaido’s mandate, a number of the legislators are in exile due to threats by the Maduro regime. Additional threats or arrests combined with political trickery could complicate the legal situation for Guaido as president of the AN. Venezuela is in a situation where power politics matters more than the bureaucratic institutional details. That said, both Maduro and Guaido make significant efforts to demonstrate that they care about the details as part of their effort to build and maintain legitimacy amid their fight over the leadership of the country. Even if Maduro somehow manipulates the National Assembly into a vote that tosses Guaido, it is near certain Guaido will reject the move as undemocratic. At that point, the international community’s commitment to the de jure government under Guaido will be tested. We will likely see a preview of that fight in the coming week at UNGA and the TIAR discussions. Saudi oil attacks: With declining production and an inability to export due to sanctions, Maduro is not in a position to take advantage of any increased prices to obtain more cash for his struggling regime. To the contrary, Reuters reported this week that PDVSA will soon need to shut down production at additional fields due to a lack of storage capacity. However, he does have two potential longer term benefits if global supplies remain tight and prices remain higher in the coming weeks. First, any increased US focus on Iran will likely decrease the focus on Venezuela. Second, China may rethink its growing restrictions on Venezuelan oil imports in a tighter global market, especially if they believe the US is less likely to enforce sanctions amid the price spike. Venezuela - Spain’s ABC reported that Mexican cartels smuggled large amounts of US currency in CLAP boxes to Costa Rica, where the money was then sent via bank transfer to Russia to pay off top drug traffickers including Tareck al-Aissami and Diosdado Cabello. Costa Rican media had previously reported that the Alunasa aluminum company had been shut down in Costa Rica due to a money laundering investigation, but the cartel bulk cash smuggling was a new angle. Meanwhile, the US Department of Treasury continued to sanction the Saab corruption network that made money by overcharging for CLAP boxes.

Despite American assertions to the contrary, private Indian refiners have continued to import oil from the country, including both Reliance Industries and Nayara Energy. Both firms struck deals to purchase crude from PDVSA well before it became subject to the U.S. sanctions. Reliance’s reported 15-year deal, beginning in 2012, allows it to buy up to 400,000 bpd. "Risk-averse companies have preferred to avoid the risk of retaliation by the Trump Administration by eschewing business with Venezuela's collapsing oil industry altogether, Reliance, and Indian energy more generally, have resisted considerably U.S. pressure and remain engaged," says Daniel Lansberg-Rodriguez, a Latin America expert at Northwestern's Kellog School of Management. The Indian government has reportedly directed at least one of the refiners to devise a payment mechanism that would avoid the U.S. banking system in an effort to avoid exposure to American secondary sanctions. Indian refiners had established a rupee-based barter system to pay for Iranian crude oil several years ago when paying in dollars was no longer an option. "The top sticking point is the status of Nicolas Maduro. Guaido’s team demands Maduro leave before elections, though there are some reports that they may be willing to be flexible on that demand if other demands for a new electoral council and new elections are met with international verification of the process. Maduro insists he will remain president and his strongest supporters (not on the negotiating team) say new elections are not even an option. COMMENT:  The date of this article is May 2nd.  I am frequently amazed when I read articles like this about things that nearly happened.  I think that the summary in the last paragraph is accurate. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/02/opinion/venezuela-maduro-guaido.html?emc=edit_th_190503&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=286991830503 A Treacherous Stalemate in Venezuela
Foreign meddling, coup plotting and bloody demonstrations heighten the tension. By The Editorial Board What the Venezuelan opposition boldly proclaimed on Tuesday as a “final phase” in the opposition’s three-month campaign to oust the Venezuelan strongman, Nicolás Maduro, fizzled out by Wednesday, leaving behind murky claims of secret talks gone wrong, defectors who didn’t defect and Russian and Cuban meddling. What comes next was even less clear than before. Announcing the final push on Tuesday morning, Juan Guaidó, the opposition leader whose claim to the Venezuelan presidency is recognized by the United States and more than 50 other countries, seemed certain that this time enough of the military would cross over to assure Mr. Maduro’s ouster. Top members of the Trump administration — Vice President Mike Pence, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and the national security adviser, John Bolton — promptly gave “Operación Libertad” their enthusiastic support. Then on Wednesday, with only a handful of national guard troops on his side, Mr. Guaidó acknowledged that it didn’t happen. Only one top Maduro official, the head of the security services, Manuel Ricardo Cristopher Figuera, appeared to have defected to him, and mass demonstrations on Wednesday were forcefully put down by security forces still loyal to Mr. Maduro. An opposition leader who had been freed from house arrest by Mr. Guaidó’s followers and initially appeared with him in public, Leopoldo López, took refuge in the Spanish Embassy in Caracas with his wife and daughter. Then the finger-pointing broke out. Mr. Maduro blamed President Trump for what he called an attempted coup d’état. Mr. Trump assailed Cuba, his usual whipping boy for Mr. Maduro’s survival, though the C.I.A. has concluded that Havana’s support is far less consequential than the administration claims. Mr. Pompeo claimed that the Russians had talked Mr. Maduro at the last moment out of boarding a plane and fleeing the country, and hinted at military intervention. The Russian foreign minister, Sergey Lavrov, warned Mr. Pompeo that “the continuation of aggressive steps is fraught with the most serious consequences.” More dramatically, Mr. Bolton claimed that there had been a secret arrangement for three Venezuelan officials — the defense minister, the chief judge of the Venezuelan Supreme Court and the commander of the presidential guard — to switch to Mr. Guaidó’s side, but that they failed to do so. The Wall Street Journal additionally reported that according to Elliott Abrams, the administration’s special envoy for Venezuela, secret talks had taken place between the opposition and top government officials about a change in government and that a legal document had been drawn up for the transition. But whether the purported deal was a trap set by Mr. Maduro to make his opponents look inept, or whether the officials got cold feet, or whether it was an effort by American officials to spread distrust and instability in the beleaguered presidential palace, remained unclear. In the end, whatever had led Mr. Guaidó and the Trump team to believe that the “final phase” was at hand, and whatever led to its collapse, the fact was that the opposition was left weaker than before in the eyes of its exhausted and impoverished followers. Mr. Guaidó called next for national strikes, but it was difficult to know how long he could continue to rouse popular protests with promises of imminent change. And as Venezuela’s humanitarian crisis grew more dire, Mr. Maduro was bound to blame it on American sanctions on Venezuelan oil, which came into full effect this week. None of that bodes well for a quick resolution of the crisis. At some point, Mr. Guaidó may have to consider negotiating directly with Mr. Maduro to find a peaceful exit from a stalemate that is compounding the suffering that Mr. Maduro’s policies, corruption and chronic mismanagement have inflicted on the Venezuelans. American military intervention, repeatedly cited as a possibility by Mr. Trump and Mr. Pompeo, remains a terrible idea. However invested the Trump administration is in the ouster of Mr. Maduro, a direct intervention would find little support across a region with bad memories of American meddling, and would brand Mr. Guaidó as an American lackey.

Guaido has said that the exit of Maduro is a non-negotiable point and he will only send a delegation to another round of negotiations if Maduro’s exit is on the table.

As June is close to be over, the percentage for Nicolas Maduro to cease to be President Venezuela will I leave to a 1% change. Moreover, the worst days of the crisis around Maduro are over, not at least because other incidents have taken precedence in international politics that require attention from the international community, therefore decreasing the factor of Maduro ceasing power due to international interference.  Beginning of June, moreover, Maduro said he would sign a deal with the IFRC to increase incoming humanitarian support to the country. This may at least lighten social tensions a little bit in some areas of the country. 
As Maduro's main motive currently is to stay in power he will find political moves, such as the deal with the IFRC that would give him credit. Moreover, he expands the dependence of the most vulnerable, the poor, in Venezuela on him, as he did with introducing CLAP the food distribution system for the very poor.  It is clear that, legally or lawfully, Maduro will not cease to be President, as his party is firmly holding onto power in every state organ. Maduro, the Supreme Court, the National Electoral Council (CNE) and the Constitutional Assembly will continue to disqualify opponents from holding office, rig electoral rules to ensure success in any electoral contest and manipulate results after elections take place. As well, opponents to the regime are jailed and protests are met with tough military crackdowns, which may still be enough to dissuade the population from taking to the streets in large numbers. As internal anti-government protests are still up and running by government oppositions and a street movement by the opposition and other opponents seems to be the most likely way to push Maduro out of power, however capacities are not met it is not likely that Maduro will be pushed out of power anytime soon. The border between Venezuela and Colombia has recently re-opened, meaning that no major deterioration seems to be in sight, either. This moreover means that citizens unhappy with the situation also have the change to migrate out of the country, rather than planning an uprising against the oppressive regime, therefore making the opposition movement loose drivers of change.

Update: 
In my last forecast on this question, I focused on factors that would initiate a coup  and as it was rightly pointed out by other forecasters, this is naturally only one way in which Maduro’s presidency would cease. Another, challenge to his hold on power in Venezuela is the prospect of an uprising.  It has been suggested that two variables that are indicative of a high potential for uprising is a high number of youths (age 15-24) and, simultaneously, high levels of corruption. The underlying hypothesis is that in highly corrupt countries, growing inequality and investment stagnation will hit the younger population especially hard, as they are not yet established in the economic system, and hence have fewer economic opportunities. From this follow that in a society characterized by a large percentage of youths and a high level of corruption, the younger population will be important agents of change and the chance of a political uprising in this scenario is therefore higher.  A high percentage of youth in the population, a so-called youth bulge, is set at min 20 %. Data from the World Bank’s show that in 2001 15-24 year old made up app. 19.3 % of the population. However, in recent years the age structure has been changing with an increase (proportionally and gross numbers) in Venezuela. In 2019, the World Bank data estimate that the youth make up app. 17% of the population. Hence, Venezuela does not have a pronouncedly large youth bulge. Moreover, it estimated that more than 4 million Venezuelans have left the country following the severe economic crisis and extreme food shortage. Reports say that 53% of people in the age of 15-29% wish to leave Venezuela. In terms of corruption, Venezuela rank extremely poorly according to Transparency International. Scoring just 18 out of 100 points, Venezuela is one of the most corrupt countries in the world.  While the current state economic crisis, and extreme corruption of state institutions, speak in favor of Maduro’s loss of power, the out-flux of young people might be of significance for Maduro’s ability to hold on to power. As youths are important actors of change, and key drivers of political uprising, the fact that they are increasingly leaving the country, could potentially impact the force of the public protests and the pressure from civil society against Maduro. Hence, I remain skeptical that Maduro will cease to be president in the near future.  Sources:

A few weeks ago, OPEC+ was mulling the possibility of exiting the production cut agreement because the oil market was at risk of over-tightening. Now Saudi Arabia is scrambling to extend the cuts and may even unilaterally lower its own production further in an effort to head off a price slide. On Monday, officials from Saudi Arabia and Russia reportedly discussed a possible scenario in which oil prices crashed below $40 per barrel, a recognition that the market has rapidly deteriorated. They view that outcome as a possibility if they can’t agree on an extension. “Today there are big risks of oversupply,” Russian Energy Minister Alexander Novak said in Moscow after meeting with Saudi oil minister Khalid al-Falih. “We’ve agreed that we need to run a deeper analysis and to see how events unfold in June.”

As I was completely floored about how to go about this forecast, I chose to look closer at the One Earth Future Research and their CoupCast program that work to predict the likelihood of a coup attempt to occur by drawing on historical data and machine learning. The research program has identified six variables that are indicative of the potential of regime overthrow. The variables are the following: 
1.	The time in which a leader has been in power (Longer leadership = higher risk of coup) 
2.	The time a regime has been in power (Younger regimes = higher risk of coup) 
3.	When the last attempt at a coup was (Little time since last coup = high risk of a re-attempt) 
4.	Defeat in election (Recent defeat = higher risk of coup) 
5.	Weather conditions (Extreme weather that interfere with agriculture or market dynamics = increased risk of coup) 
6.	GDPPC (Indicative of a ruling leader’s ability to buy their opponent) 
I will attempt for the above parameters in relation to the current situation in Venezuela as a basis for my prediction on when Nicolas Maduro will cease to be president of Venezuela.   1.	Nicolas Maduro was elected president in 2013 and had been in office not a full term before elections were called in 2018. Hence, the length of this time in power does not count toward an increased risk of immediate coup. However, it is worth noticing that the experienced protests to his presidency already 1 year into his first term in 2014. (Low risk) 2.	The regime here is understood as Maduro’s own political basis: The Socialist Party. The Socialist party is well-established haven enjoyed political prominence since its foundation in the late 1990s by Hugo Chavez. (Low risk) 3.	The last coup attempt in Venezuela was in 2002, against the late Hugo Chavez  initiated by high ranking members of the military. The coup kept Chavez out of office for less than 50 hours, and as such failed. (Low risk) 4.	Technically, Maduro has not lost a presidential election, and the Socialist Party has, in one form or another, been in power since the 1999. However, while Maduro did not lose in 2018, the election is at the heart of the Venezuelan conflict in that it was considered invalid, and declared so, by the National Assembly. (Medium risk) 5.	Venezuela has not considered any abnormal downpour in recent time. (Low risk) 6.	The Venezuelan economy is in extreme crisis. Inflation is expected to reach 10 million % and the country is essentially experiencing a total breakdown in trade and consumption. The economy is in free fall and while that currently allows for the Maduro to pay his way to remain in power, the situation could quickly become so dire that this will no longer be an option. (High risk) This rudimentary analysis indicates that the economy is currently the only factor that indicates a pending coup in Venezuela, and therefore a high unlikelihood, of Maduro ceasing to be president of Venezuela. However, the model does not account for the tensions of the international political society, where nations actors like the US and EU have acknowledged Juan Guaido as President of Venezuela. Similarly, countries like Russia and Turkey have supported Maduro’s claim to power. Also, while Maduro did not lose the election, his victory has been denied by the General Assembly and considering that a democratic election is only worth the legitimacy is can claim, this ‘not-defeat’ does not speak in his favor. Moreover, while the extreme weather has not interfered with food production, the economy is currently is such shambles that food shortage is a real and extremely serious issue in Venezuela. Hence, this lack of basic security does not count in Maduro’s favor. While Maduro has been able to secure the support of the military, this ally to has wavered with some high-ranking officers expressing their support for Guaido. Additionally, through his reference to Venezuelan constitution, national support, international recognition and budding support from the military, Guaido has positioned himself as real and tangible alternative to Maduro.   In conclusion, following the first part of the analysis, it seems a coup is not in the immediate future. However, considering the many complicating factor’s around the current situation in Venezuela, it does not seem likely that Maduro will stay in power throughout this presidential term. Considering the options above, I ascribe 88 % probability of Maduro not ceasing to be president till after January 1st 2020.  Sources:

Venezuela's crude production has dropped to around 500,000 b/d as sluggish export loadings and replete storage force state-owned PdV to shut in wells, four company officials tell Argus. The decline is most pronounced in the Orinoco heavy oil belt, where production has dwindled to less than 200,000 b/d in recent days, compared with more than 700,000 b/d in early May. The oil belt is traditionally the largest source of Venezuelan crude, but US oil sanctions have exacerbated underlying operational problems to stifle flows. A year ago the oil belt was producing around 1mn b/d.

Nicolas Maduro has already proven to have the capabilities to stay in power no matter how bad the political and economic environment of Venezuela is. The crisis in Venezuela began in 2014, when Hugo Chavez was the president of Venezuela and the crisis has been affecting lives of citizens, making it miserable to reside in the country. However, despite internal and international pressure on Maduro, he’s been the president of Venezuela since 2013 and I assume that he won’t cease to be president of Venezuela before January 1 of 2020. Below I’ll be discussing the major international and internal challenges for his presidency. International pressure is one of the most significant challenges for Maduro. Venezuela owns the world’s largest supply of crude oil. Additionally, petroleum products are major part of the country’s exports. However, oil output has been declining. In January 2019 the US government imposed sanctions on Venezuela’s state-owned oil company PDVSA. However, the company can avoid sanctions if they recognize Juan Guaido as a president. The sanctions left Venezuela’s oil-dependent economy without its biggest source. Currently Venezuela is desperately looking for new buyers. Even though Venezuela now is exporting more oil to India, it’s still not enough and 10 million barrels of oil have been sitting off in the tankers. Besides, the exports to China have been dropping as well and Asian market isn’t that attractive to Venezuela, since it means increased transport costs, while the Venezuelan ports aren’t technically equipped to deliver oil to long distances. It also needs to be noted that there are still countries like Russia, China, Turkey, Iran and several others that still support Maduro’s regime. The member states of the EU, the US and other countries support Juan Guaido as interim president. However, the support from the countries like Russia and China strengthens Maduro’s position. Furthermore, the possibility of international intervention has been on international agenda for awhile, but needs to be noted that it’s almost impossible in this case. Most likely it would be the US to use military forces against Venezuela. However, even though Trump has hinted several times of such actions, he won’t be able to get support from the Senate, as emphasized by the Democratic chairman of the House Foreign affairs committee.  The two major internal challenges for Maduro are Juan Guaido and the military support. Guaido has support from people as well as all the political parties that recognize him as a legitimate president. However, Maduro has demonstrated through his actions and the overall situation of the country is also a proof, that the fact that his people are suffering doesn’t really bother him. He has military support, that is crucial for his presidency. It’s obvious that if he loses military support, he won’t be able to stay in power. However, military forces are now getting money from Maduro and with another person coming to power, they will lose the source of income and power along with it. Most likely they will be punished for their actions as well. Hence, I assume they will stay loyal to Maduro’s regime as long as possible.  To sum up, I believe the above mentioned facts can at the same time be reason for him to cease being a president. Therefore, leaving some space for this option (in total 35% probability). However, he’s been overcoming all the obstacles during his presidency for 6 years already, that makes me assume that he will remain the  president of Venezuela until January 2020.  Sources:  https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-47239060 https://www.telesurenglish.net/news/US-Congress-Rejects-Trumps-Warmongering-Wont-Support-Military-Intervention-in-Venezuela-20190213-0017.html https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-46999668 https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/04/opinion/venezuela-military-maduro-guaido.html https://www.foxbusiness.com/politics/military-action-possible-in-venezuela-pompeo-says#

President Trump is questioning his administration’s aggressive strategy in Venezuela following the failure of a U.S.-backed effort to oust President Nicolás Maduro, complaining he was misled about how easy it would be to replace the socialist strongman with a young opposition figure, according to administration officials and White House advisers.

Update:  The military is at the center of the balance of power in Venezuela, thereby a crucial institution for one who leads the State. On April 30th, I believed that the attempt for a “coup” illustrated a shift of the military support from Maduro to Guaido. However, the coup failed, and was driven only by a small deficient group. Moreover, the mobilization surrounding Guaido’s initiative for turning back to Maduro by influencing the military, did not gather many people at the demonstrations, last week end.  In that sense, I would like to assign the same probabilities as firstly forecasted, that is, with a higher probability for “not before 1st January 2020”. I assign a higher probability to this option because foreign intervention becomes less and less likely (Trump’s latest declarations for instance) and also, thinking of several scenarios during the Arab Spring, where the military remained loyal to the power and suppressed the crisis e.g Saudi Arabia.  The peak of the crisis is seemingly not over, contrary to what I had previously forecasted. We are witnessing the opening of a new chapter of the Venezuelan crisis, with no more improvement although the small opening of hope on April 30th 2019. Nevertheless, I would like to pinpoint a high uncertainty in this forecast. Indeed, the military seems to be particularly loyal to Maduro, however, this could change sooner or later. But I would not forecast a change for the upcoming weeks. I believe that new dynamics  to the crisis are yet to come and will gradually draw perspective to the situation. Hence, I am still assigning a fair probability for a political change, this year. This forecast is based on the assumption that Maduro will be President until January 2020 (highest probability). If I consider a good probability for a change this year, I would rather expect this to happen after additional weeks/ months of confrontations, taking into account the current upheaval. However, if Maduro remains President through the summer, that is, he succeeded at keeping the military close, I do not expect him to cease to be President after this period (as a certain balance would have returned potentially from this fact) https://www.lemonde.fr/international/article/2019/05/05/au-venezuela-guaido-courtise-l-armee-a-laquelle-maduro-demande-de-se-tenir-prete_5458378_3210.html

Update #5: As stated in my original forecast, arguably, the support of the military and the security forces are the crucial point with regard to the survival chances of the Maduro regime. To this effect, this week posed both, signs of support for the regime within the security forces, as frictions. On the one hand, opposition leader Juan Guaidó had stood in front of a group of soldiers, on Tuesday, and assured the population by video message that the army was now turning around to free Venezuela from its “oppressor” Maduro and by that started “Operation Freedom” However, despite demonstrators flocked to the military base in Caracas, only a few, about fifty soldiers, turned over to the opposition. Instead, the army leadership reassured Maduro of its allegiance and proved it by sending its soldiers out into the streets to break up the demonstrations. On the other hand, the liberation of the opposition leader Leopoldo López from house arrest, on the same day, was a great success for the opposition. López, who led the protests of 2014, has been in prison since then and is considered Guaidó's political foster father. He was apparently released by secret service officials - a sign of the cracks in Maduro's security apparatus, at least in the secret service. This is also supported by the fact that the commander of the secret service addressed Maduro in a letter in which he spoke of a "renewal of the state".  This stalemate made me adapt my forecast, that estimated a very high survival chance for the Maduro regime a bit in favor of the opposition, adding a 10% probability on a cease of the Maduro Regime before June 30, now 20%, and reducing the estimated likelihood of cease not before January 1, by 10%, towards now 70%.

This forecast will assess the internal and external pressures to Maduro and his administration in order to compare them with other regime changes and to derive an estimated ‘likelihood of transition’ in Venezuela. The assessed internal pressure will be mainly comprised of support by the military elites and ordinary Venezuelans. The outside pressure is represented in the support or opposition of foreign states who have to some degree influence on Venezuela’s politics (international big players such as USA, but also regional neighbours like Colombia).  The first aspect to assess is the loyalty of the military to Maduro and Guaido due to its powerful position within the country. Not only do the heads of the military branches possess significant power by themselves, current and former military personnel also occupy important positions within the Venezuelan political system and state-owned corporations in key areas, especially the oil sector (such as PdVSA). The military elite, therefore, dominates the political system and furthermore controls the main income of Venezuela. Their support and loyalty can make the difference in internal and external politics. The question is: how loyal is the military to Maduro or how likely are they to defect to Guaido? At this point of time, it seems that the higher levels of command are still loyal to Maduro. The socialist government ensures this loyalty by granting generals and higher officers privileges in regard to positions and wealth distribution. As a result, by deflecting to Guaido, these officers would risk losing their privileges, thus, decreasing the likelihood of them running over to the opposition. On the other side, low ranked military personnel seem more likely to defect as they don’t enjoy the same privileges and, contrary to the military elites, face similar issues as ordinary Venezuelans such as a high inflation which undermines their purchasing power, as well as negative impacts on themselves and their families through missing public services (e.g.: health, food, education, etc.). Indeed, in the last months there were armed forces who changed their sides in favour of the opposition. Most of them classify as low ranked military personnel with only a few defectors from higher ranks (especially air force Gen. F. Yanez & head of the secret police M.R.C. Figuera), thus, affirming the assumptions made above. However, the numbers of renegades aren’t high enough to indicate a significant change of loyalty in the military forces. Furthermore, the liberated opposition leader Leopoldo Lopez, as well as some armed forces loyal to Guaido, requested asylum in foreign embassies shortly after the Tuesday demonstration which indicates that the protest didn’t manage to shift the tides in favour of Guaido. This raises the question why there aren’t more defectors among lower ranks regarding the fact that they face the same issues as Venezuelan citizens? The answer might lie in the widespread and deep infiltration of the military through the intelligence services. As some analysts and commentators in international media argue, the insecurity posed through this infiltration decreases the motivation and, thus, the likelihood of waves of defectors running over to Guaido. It also seems that the Maduro regime focuses on breaking opposition cells within the armed forces to prevent a shift in loyalty (by using infamous death squads). Guaido himself admitted that his protest at the 30.04.2019 failed due to the lack of military defectors (BBC 2019).  Guaido is still able to mobilize large crowds of civilian protesters in Caracas. It seems that his support base hasn’t lost its faith in him. However, so far Guaido avoided to march with this crowd towards symbolic institutions, such as the president’s palace, which may indicate that Guaido himself doesn’t believe to have enough supporters who are willing to actively protest on the streets for him. The recent march to an air force base represents a new level of escalation which, if continued, may lead to pro-Guaido supporters marching towards the president palace. This could either lead to a high enough pressure to convince Maduro to step down or to a bloody confrontation comparable to the Maidan revolution in Ukraine 2014 which in turn would enable foreign states to intervene. It is very likely that the already precarious circumstances will worsen in the next months which implies a potential for Guaido to increase his support base, nevertheless, his recruiting potential declines steadily if he doesn’t manage to achieve significant successes in order to limit negative effects on his supporter’s motivation. On the other hand, Maduro himself can rely on public support, too. His socialist party remains one of the most popular and his regime gains support amongst Venezuelans for state support in form of free food supplies and medical care (despite that these became very scarce). Furthermore, Maduro gains further popularity as he is seen as someone who resist the influence of “imperialist forces” (Venezuelan socialist fear an increased influence of the USA within their country). However, the involved uncertainties and the lack of reliable survey data makes it very difficult to assess who managed to gather more public support in Venezuela.  Additional to these internal factors, this forecast will also focus on external support or opposition by foreign states for/to the Maduro regime. For this purpose, it will mainly focus on the stances of Latin American states, the USA, the EU, Russia and other relevant states. The majority of Latin American states supports Guaido as legitimate interim president. Especially Brazil and Colombia oppose Maduro and requested from him to stand down, but Brazil’s president declared on the 1st of May that his country won’t intervene in Venezuela. Contrary to them, there is a minority which still supports Maduro as legitimate president (Bolivia, Nicaragua and Suriname). Cuba in particular is a main ally of the Maduro regime and supports it by providing additional military forces and other vital supplies. Both countries have a common history of friendship as they share more or less the same ideology. At the global scale there are mainly two blocs. The pro-Guaido bloc comprising several European states, Canada, Australia and Georgia headed by the US on the one side and the pro-Maduro bloc lead by Russia including China, Turkey, Greece and Iran on the other side. The US Secretary of State recently (01.05.2019) declared that his country would be willing to intervene militarily if a peaceful transition would be suppressed by the Maduro regime. The US and its allies already targeted the Venezuelan government by imposing sanctions on government officials and state-owned corporations and their subsidiaries, thus, de-facto isolating Venezuela from trade and the global markets, as well as freezing assets of regime loyal officials. On the other site, Russia is alleged to support the Maduro regime by providing funds, military equipment and assistants in internal espionage against the opposition. The Russian government often stressed their intentions and commitment to prevent a regime change and warned, especially the US, to overthrow the regime from the outside which decreases the likelihood for an US military intervention. Other pro-Maduro states take a more passive stance towards the issue by avoiding a direct confrontation with the US. For instance, China and Turkey continue their trade relations with Venezuela despite imposed sanctions from the US and the EU, thus, supporting the Maduro administration indirectly through trade revenue. India, which hasn’t stated support for any faction, also continues to import oil from Venezuela, hence, keeping the crisis-shaken petroleum industry alive.  To conclude, Maduro and his regime seem to be able maintaining the loyalty of the Venezuelan military elite as it is unlikely that a majority of this elite will defect to Guaido regarding their unique privileges and favourable positions owing to the civil-military alliance drafted by Chavez. However, Guaido has a chance to convince low ranking military personnel to join him as they don’t receive these privileges. Two factors seem to be decisive for this to happen: a) there has to be a momentum within the Venezuelan Army which convinces soldiers to defect and b) the grip of the intelligence services on the armed forces soften (by a lack of resources or through defectors in their own units). The sooner this happens the more likely it is that the military elite will be overthrown by its lower ranks which would be a vital hit to Maduro’s ability to hold on his power. Contrary to this, more time for the Maduro regime means that the gradual losses of defecting soldiers can be substituted by Cuban army personnel, hence, decreasing the overall likelihood for a successful bottom-up uprising within Venezuela’s armed forces. Therefore, the Venezuelan situation cannot be compared to Egypt’s regime change during the Arab spring when the military elite decided to abandon its former president. The popular support of Guaido might be higher than Maduro’s, however, so far none of the protests and events imposed a truly critical danger to Maduro. As a result, other successful regime changes in the Arab Spring (such as Tunisia) aren’t good comparisons neither as the protesters there managed to gain a momentum and successfully increased the pressure fast enough to the point where their former government had no choice other than standing down. While Maduro faces firm opposition in the international community, he also receives vital support from key international actors. Especially Russia and China will block any decisive agreements against him within the UN Security Council. Furthermore, Maduro has a strong fundament to sustain the political turmoil in his country due to the support of Russia and Cuba. This fact makes it unlikely that there will be a regime change like the ones in Afghanistan, Iraq or Libya. The circumstances of the Venezuelan crisis, internal and external, mirror to some degree the situation Syria faces (except the missing civil war). In both countries, the majority of the military elite remained loyal to the president (despite prominent defectors in high ranks). Also, the population is split between the sides (Al-Assad was backed by the ethnical and religious minorities in his countries who feared a Sunni-majority led government at the beginning of the conflict. However, after a short time the factions split into several parts which ended the binary actor situation). The strongest argument for the similarity between Syria and Venezuela is the complex regional and international environment where different actors supported their favourite factions within the country and helped them to survive. Regarding the Syrian development it seems very unlikely that Maduro will cease to be president if Guaido doesn’t manage to get rid of him soon. Another conflict, which isn’t as similar as Syria, is the Ukraine conflict. It proves that the Russian Federation is willing to defend its strategic interest despite Western opposition. It could be argued that the Russian state is less likely to support Venezuela to the same degree as it backed Ukrainian separatists and Al-Assad due to decreasing resources, however, the involvement of China which supports Maduro’s regime indirectly could easily substitute for the lack of Russian resources.  As a result, this forecast estimates that there is a moderate likelihood for Maduro to cease being president between 1 April 2019 and 30 June 2019 as Guaido will very likely try to force a regime change. However, this likelihood is assessed to drop sharply for the options which comprise the time period between 1 July 2019 and 31 December 2019 as Maduro will be able to consolidate his power with the help of foreign supporters. Currently there is a momentum for Guaido, nevertheless, it doesn’t seem to achieve a critical level of support to become dangerous for Maduro. As a result, this forecast assesses that the likelihood for a regime change is less likely than Maduro remaining president.  Sources:

Update: new developments in Venezuela are cause for reconsidering this question. Yesterday, Guaidò called for an uprising against Maduro at a military base in the capital. This is an instrumental step in the Venezuelan crisis, illustrating increasing military support for Guaidò. As described in previous forecasts, Maduro's military backing to date has been a critical component in his capacity to remain in power. It was determined in the same forecasts that for Maduro to cease to be president before January 1st 2020, it would most likely be the outcome of a successful military coup. With an evident shift in military backing, and Guaidò's apparent ability to mobilise action, a successful coup now seems more possible than ever. The forecast is adjusted to account for Guaidò's current momentum and the prospect of more military personnel switching sides -- that Maduro ceases to be president before June 30 is forecasted to be 40%. But given Maduro's ability to withstand major crises and the statistical unlikelihood of a successful coup, if he is able to survive the coming weeks it is likely he will endure until the end of the year. Thus, the prospect of Maduro being removed after July 1 and before December 31 is considered highly likely -- given 3% and 2% respectively per time frame. 55% is given to the final option, that Maduro will still be president at the end of the year -- this has been lowered from previous evaluations to account for the increasing possibility that Maduro will be removed in the coming weeks.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-erikprince-exclusi/exclusive-blackwater-founders-latest-sales-pitch-mercenaries-for-venezuela-idUSKCN1S608F APRIL 29, 2019  Erik Prince - the founder of the controversial private security firm Blackwater and a prominent supporter of U.S. President Donald Trump - has been pushing a plan to deploy a private army to help topple Venezuela’s socialist president . . .  Over the last several months, the sources said, Prince has sought investment and political support for such an operation from influential Trump supporters and wealthy Venezuelan exiles. In private meetings in the United States and Europe, Prince sketched out a plan to field up to 5,000 soldiers-for-hire on behalf of Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaido, . . . One source said Prince has conducted meetings about the issue as recently as mid-April. White House National Security Council spokesman Garrett Marquis declined to comment when asked whether Prince had proposed his plan to the government and whether it would be considered. A person familiar with the administration’s thinking said the White House would not support such a plan. Venezuela opposition officials have not discussed security operations with Prince, said Guaido spokesman . . .  Some U.S. and Venezuelan security experts, told of the plan by Reuters, called it politically far-fetched and potentially dangerous because it could set off a civil war. A Venezuelan exile close to the opposition agreed but said private contractors might prove useful, in the event Maduro’s government collapses, by providing security for a new administration in the aftermath. A spokesman for Prince, Marc Cohen, said this month that Prince “has no plans to operate or implement an operation in Venezuela” and declined to answer further questions. Lital Leshem - the director of investor relations at Prince’s private equity firm, Frontier Resource Group - earlier confirmed Prince’s interest in Venezuela security operations. “He does have a solution for Venezuela, just as he has a solution for many other places,” she said, declining to elaborate on his proposal. The two sources with direct knowledge of Prince’s pitch said it calls for starting with intelligence operations and later deploying 4,000 to 5,000 soldiers-for-hire from Colombia and other Latin American nations to conduct combat and stabilization operations.
. . . 
One of Prince’s key arguments, one source said, is that Venezuela needs what Prince calls a “dynamic event” to break the stalemate that has existed since January,. . .  . . .  Key government institutions – including the military – have not shifted their loyalty to Guaido despite increasing international pressure from sanctions imposed by the United States and its allies. Guaido has stressed that he wants a peaceful resolution, and Latin American governments recognizing his authority have urged against outside military action. Senior U.S. officials, without ruling out armed intervention, have also emphasized economic and diplomatic measures to pressure Maduro. Prince was a pioneer in private military contracting during the Iraq war, when the U.S. government hired Blackwater primarily to provide security for State Department operations there. In 2007, Blackwater employees shot and killed 17 Iraqi civilians at Nisour Square in Baghdad, sparking international outrage. One of the Blackwater employees involved was convicted of murder in December and three others have been convicted of manslaughter. Prince renamed the Blackwater security company and sold it in 2010, but he recently opened a company called Blackwater USA, which sells ammunition, silencers and knives. Over the past two years, he has led an unsuccessful campaign to convince the Trump administration to replace U.S. soldiers in Afghanistan with security contractors.
. . . 
Prince donated $100,000 to a political action committee that supported Trump’s election. His sister, Betsy DeVos, is the administration’s education secretary.     Prince’s role in Trump’s campaign was highlighted in the report by Special Prosecutor Robert Mueller, . . . 
    The report outlined how Prince financed an effort to authenticate purported Hillary Clinton emails and how in 2016 he met in the Seychelles islands, off east Africa, with a wealthy Russian financial official on behalf of Trump’s presidential transition team.
. . . 
The two sources with direct knowledge of Prince’s Venezuela plan said he is seeking $40 million from private investors. He also aims to get funding from the billions of dollars in Venezuelan assets that have been seized by governments around the world imposing sanctions on the OPEC nation, a major oil exporter. It’s unclear, however, how the Venezuelan opposition could legally access those assets. Prince told people in pitch meetings, the sources said, that he believes that Guaido has the authority to form his own military force because he has been recognized internationally as Venezuela’s rightful leader. Prince envisions a force made up of “Peruvians, Ecuadoreans, Colombians, Spanish speakers,” one of the sources said, adding that Prince argued that such soldiers would be more politically palatable than American contractors.

 . . . at anti-government protests . . . Several dozen armed troops accompanying Guaido clashed with soldiers . . . but the incident fizzled out and did not appear to be part of an immediate attempt by the opposition to take power through military force. Guaido, in a video posted on Twitter earlier on Tuesday, wrote that he had begun the “final phase” of his campaign to topple Maduro, calling on Venezuelans and the armed forces to back him ahead of May Day mass street protests planned for Wednesday.
. . . 
Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino called the latest instability a “coup movement” but several hours after Guaido’s announcement there was no sign of any other anti-Maduro military activity and no immediate reports of casualties. Guaido later left a rally he was holding with military supporters at the air base. Repeated opposition attempts to force Maduro, a socialist, from power through huge protests and calls on the military to act have so far failed. Maduro said on Tuesday he had spoken with military leaders and that they had shown him “their total loyalty.”
. . . 
The move was Guaido’s boldest effort yet to persuade the military to rise up against Maduro. If it fails, it could be seen as evidence that he lacks the support he says he has. It might also encourage the authorities, who have already stripped him of parliamentary immunity and opened multiple investigations into him, to arrest him.
. . . 
Guaido’s efforts appeared aimed at building momentum toward the May Day mass street protests and making them a turning point in his push to oust Maduro.  Guaido has said Wednesday’s protests will be “the largest march in Venezuela’s history” and part of what he calls the “definitive phase” of his effort to take office in order to call fresh elections.
. . . 
Guaido, the leader of Venezuela’s opposition-controlled National Assembly, in January invoked the constitution to assume an interim presidency, arguing that Maduro’s re-election in 2018 was illegitimate. U.S. President Donald Trump “has been briefed and is monitoring the ongoing situation,” White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders said on Tuesday. The White House declined to comment on whether the administration had been consulted or had advance knowledge of what Guaido was planning. U.S. national security adviser John Bolton appeared to back Guaido’s actions on Tuesday. “The FANB must protect the Constitution and the Venezuelan people. It should stand by the National Assembly and the legitimate institutions against the usurpation of democracy,” Bolton tweeted, referring to the FANB armed forces. Conservative Republicans in Washington welcomed the reports from Venezuela. Senator Marco Rubio, a hard-liner on Venezuela, urged Venezuelans to take to the streets: “Do not allow this moment to slip away. It may not come again,” he wrote on Twitter. Brazil’s right-wing President Jair Bolsonaro expressed his nation’s solidarity for the people of Venezuela, who he said were “enslaved by a dictator.” Venezuelan Information Minister Jorge Rodriguez on Tuesday tweeted that the government was confronting a small group of “military traitors” seeking to promote a coup.
. . . 
Maduro, for his part, has appeared to retain control of state institutions and the loyalty of senior military officers and has foreign allies such as Russia and Cuba. Russia’s foreign ministry on Tuesday accused the Venezuelan opposition of resorting to violence in what it said was a brazen attempt to draw the country’s armed forces into clashes. Maduro has called Guaido a U.S-backed puppet who seeks to oust him in a coup. The government has arrested his top aide, stripped Guaido of his parliamentary immunity and opened multiple probes. It has also barred him from leaving the country, a ban Guaido openly violated earlier this year. Last week, Guaido said his congressional ally - opposition lawmaker Gilber Caro - had been detained, and that 11 members of his team had been summoned to appear before the Sebin intelligence agency. Lopez, seen with Guaido, appeared to have left his home for the first time since being placed under house arrest in 2017, after three years in jail. “I have been freed by soldiers on the side of the constitution and President Guaido,” he tweeted. All of us have to mobilize. It’s time to win our freedom.” A soldier in the group with Guaido, who identified himself just as Rivas, denied government accusations that they had been tricked into backing Guaido. “We’re all afraid,” he told Reuters, “but we had to do it”.

Maduro has demonstrated that he will not step down in the face of massive disorder and riots. If he was going to be swayed by protests and international pressure, he wouldn't have cracked down so hard and would've given indication of his abdication by now. That fact that he hasn't indicates that he is not a leader swayed by public opinion nor international pressure. The latter of which rings true of Valenzuela's anti imperialist socialist revolution.  Thereby Maduro is the type of leader does not seek to uphold democratic values of his country and will suppress his own people to remain in power and does not care what the world or citizens thinks of it. This  type of leader is one that often remain in power until they are forced out through coups, internal political struggles or become sick/elderly.  As to his age and health, Maduro is 56 and seemingly in good health. So I find there to be 0% chance of him stepping down from his presidency by the start of 2020 due to these reasons.  Which means if he was to cease to be president by 2020 it would have to be by an internal or external coup or mounting political pressure from Venezuelan elites.  At this point in time the protests have been primarily orchestrated by and for the masses. While some elites may be dissatisfied, the ones who remain in important places to pressure Maduro have been primarily shielded by the crisis that has hit Venezuela and they owe this to Maduro. For the most part Maduro has been generous in his dealings with military and political elites, thereby buying their loyalty because without Maduro they would be thrust into the current economic crisis. This is especially true of the Military's top brass who have shown unwavering support for Maduro. Thereby, I conclude that Maduro will not face enough internal pressure by 2020 to decide to resign. I also conclude that there will not by a top level coup, the type which is often most effective, against Maduro. This leaves an internal bottom level coup and an external coup as options to remove Maduro. I predict that there will be no external coups attempts on Maduro by 2020. This type of coup would most likely be orchestrated by the US. While Trump does have the personality to desire and order a coup, such plans take a long time to formulate and put in action. If a coup was being planned, it only would've begun earlier this year and I find it highly unlikely they would implement it within a year. Furthermore, I do not think this option is being seriously considered for two reasons. For one, Maduro is supported by Russia and China, two states the US is not eager to enrage over the possibility of maybe deposing Maduro. Secondly, a US backed coup would not be supported by a majority of Americans, whom are fatigued and tired of US involvement in military conflicts. Furthermore, presidential elections are nearing and campaigning has begun, which leaves the White House open to a lot of criticism.  So the last option is an international bottom level coup/civil war. I do believe this is possible. There are many documented cases in history of mid level military commanders orchestrating coups. However, the Maduro Government is on high alert and claims to have already uncovered and squashed coup attempts. These types of coups are definitely harder to orchestrate, implement  and keep secret resulting in a lower likelihood of success. I think it is possible, but highly unlikely, thereby I attribute a 1% chance it could happen and be successful between July and September 30th and a 3% chance it could happen and be successful between October 1st and December 31st.  Finally there could be a civil war. I find that this is the most likely outcome due to the fact that many soldiers in the army have been defecting and Guaidó is actively encouraging this and offering pardons for those who support him. However, if a civil war does break out, civil wars are often long and not focused on removing opposition leaders,  especially considering that  given Maduro's  disposition thus far, I find that he'll more than likely decide to fight the civil war rather than step down to prevent it. Thereby, I give a 1% chance that a civil war could remove Maduro between October 1st and December 31st.

The United States imported exactly zero barrels of crude from Venezuela last week, according to government statistics. That's never happened since the US Energy Information Administration began tracking this weekly metric in 2010.
It marks a sharp decline from the prior week, when the United States imported 112,000 barrels per day from Venezuela. The plunge in oil shipments from Venezuela helped lift US oil prices above $60 a barrel this week for the first time since November. President Donald Trump imposed tough sanctions on Venezuela in January in an effort to punish the regime of Nicolas Maduro and speed its demise.
But US Gulf Coast refineries have long relied on Venezuela's heavy grade of crude to churn out gasoline, jet fuel and diesel that keep the American economy humming. Just a year ago, Venezuela shipped more than half a million barrels of oil per day to US shores, making the Latin American country one of America's largest suppliers.
"I suspect it will stay at zero. It's a big problem for US refiners," said Ryan Fitzmaurice, energy strategist at Rabobank. "We really do need that heavy crude that comes from Venezuela. We're finding it difficult to source it from elsewhere."

In addition to everyday political threats, leaders risk removal from office through coups and mass movements such as rebellion. Further, all leaders face threats from shocks such as downturns in their health, their country’s economy, or their government’s revenue. By integrating these risks into the selectorate theory, we characterize the conditions under which each threat is pertinent and the countermoves (purges, democratization, expansion of public goods, and expansion of private benefits) that best enable the leader to survive in office. The model identifies new insights into the nature of assassins; the relative risk of different types of leader removal as a function of the extant institutions of government; and the endogenous factors driving better or worse public policy and decisions to democratize or become more autocratic. Importantly, the results highlight how an increase in the risk of deposition via one means intensifies other removal risks

There are a couple of significant factors why I think that Maduro will remain in power at least until January 2020. 
First, military support. I think the military plays a huge role in helping Maduro to stay in power. Even though a multilateral body called Lima Group expects that their proposed sanctions against military officials will force them to turn their backs to the president, I wouldn't consider that sanctions would have such high efficiency. Another issue is fragmented and divided opposition. Hence, there is not a huge danger coming from political opponents. 
Third, it is obvious that Maduro is strongly pressed by the UN, EU. United States even recognised opposition leader Juan Guaidó as interim leader. However, there are such countries like Russia and China (often and Turkey) that usually are very willing to take a stand against Europe and the United States while supporting dictatorships. 
Fourth, and probably the hardest thing to admit, after some time countries are very likely to get tired of pressuring Venezuela and step back. Annexed Crimea's case and Venezuela's situation are not very familiar. However, it shares the same IR practice. Even though in the case of annexed Crimea, Russia is still facing sanctions, we can see that the situation is almost normalised. Therefore, that would be my guess for Venezuela as well. Military intervention is very unlikely in this case.  On the other hand, Venezuela is in a huge humanitarian crisis. People's dissatisfaction and unrest are growing with every single day. Therefore, there are many factors that can come together, create so-called a perfect storm and determine the end of Maduro's regime. Therefore, I leave 30 % likelihood that it can happen during 2019. I think that the most likely outcome is that Maduro will remain in place as president until 1.1.2020. The reason is that he has so far retained control of the countries security forces in the face of widespread protest, famine and recent power outages etc. 
The probability estimate of 65 % reflects that the crisis is very bad, and that there is a viable political alternative candidate who have been recognised as legitimate by many EU countries and the US. These facts decrease the probability that Maduro will remain in power.
I have given the remaining options nearly the same probabilities, with the differences accounting for me assuming that the pressure for Maduro either to step down voluntarily or be forced out will continue to grow slightly with time if conditions in Venezuela remain as they are, which seem likely. I have Included the option of a US intervention in the probabilities, which I judge to be very low. The US have not intervened militarily after the Cold War, but have instead relied on economic sanction or support.

This forecast is based on the steady increase in civil unrest in Venezuela, especially seen in light of the developments over the past week (week10-11 2019), where widespread power cuts have been reported, affecting for example the hospitals (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-47512386). This has lead to a call for a national emergency by Juan Guadio and his supporters, this has to this date not been implemented. 
I am also considering the fact that Maduro is refusing to even negotiate his position as President, leading to more protesters taking to the street, which again has meant that Maduro has increased the police presence in the streets. People are growing more impatient with Maduro, especially following the blackouts and the lack of action taken to fix the issue, increasing tensions. From where I stand it seems that the people will not tolerate much more of Maduro's power play, and the situation could escalate quickly (https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/01/venezuela-crisis-latest-updates-190123205835912.html). With that being said, I do not believe he will be out off office before April 1st, as that date is fast approaching. Therefore I think it is realistic that this instead will happen between 1 April 2019 and 30 June 2019.

I am changing my forecast.  My thinking was influenced by events right after Maduro’s second term inauguration in January.  With the rapid-firing events, it is easy to imagine a rapid collapse of the Maduro government then.  But it appears that things are settling down now and it will be a long haul for a potential change in the Venezuela government.   Rationale: Shortly after the inauguration of Maduro second term, Guaido was declared to be the interim President by the National Assembly.  About 50 countries recognized Guaido as the Venezuela leader soon afterwards.  These include the Lima Group, many South American countries, US, and a dozen European countries (but not the EU which could not come up with a consensus among its 28 members).  It is followed by massive demonstrations with some loss of life.  One high ranking air force general and some diplomats declared their allegiance to Guaido. While all these events are favorable to Guaido, it appears that the momentum has stalled.  The humanitarian aids organized by Guaido and his allies have been stopped at the border.  It has been speculated that the entry of these aids would result in massive defection of the soldiers, but it did not happen.  Furthermore there was no additional defection by more high ranking officers. The path for Guaido is narrow; it is either external pressure or internal defection.   Extension pressure could come as military intervention or economic sanction.  The only possible military intervention is from the US.  But it is unlike as Trump is mired in his own problems and Pence has declared that the US has no timeline for Venezuela [1].  Venezuela has endured economic problems (including sanctions) for a long time since the first Maduro term in 2013.  But his regime withstood years of demonstrations (some of which are violent), hyperinflation, mass migration out of the country and lack of food and medicine.  Further sanctions could result in regime change but very slowly, if at all.   The only quick way to power for Guaido is through military support.  So far most of the military establishment is not siding with him even though he has been wooing them and clemency was even offered.  It would take more action from Guado to facilitate the military to abandon Maduro. I don’t know what that is that he can do as he and his allies have tried all the things described above already. Recently there are power outages throughout the country.  I don’t know what caused those, but it is possible that they are due to sabotage from Guaido's allies (another thing to try).  The blackouts would further destabilizes the government.  But I don’t see the military would turn because of that. I am not being optimistic here.  It looks like the only path for a regime change is a civil war (remember Maduro has the support of the military as well as about 25% of the population [3] which benefited from Chavez’s socialist policy).  The Venezuelans has lived through 6 years of upheaval with Maduro already.   One way or the other, change will take a long time to come. Amid ongoing protests and Guaidó’s declaration of presidency on 23 January, the political crisis in Venezuela has reared its head.  While the US, Canada and some European and Latin American countries have backed Guaidó’s presidency, he has little legitimate power at this stage. Maduro still stands as elected president — while this is highly controversial and contested — and shows little indication of conceding defeat despite large international opposition. This is partly because Maduro’s position has been strengthened by Russia and China, who have supported Maduro and blocked the UN Security Council’s push to back Guaidó (CNN 24 Jan 2019; Reuters 5 Feb 2019). Venezuela is thus in a leadership impasse, and the plausible scenarios for which Maduro will cease to be president must be considered in order to make a reasonable forecast.  1.  Voluntary resignation. Based on his actions to date, this is improbable.  2. International military intervention. Despite intervention in the form of US and EU sanctions, a physical military intervention is not foreseeable. The embargo is the best option to cripple Maduro logistically, strategically and operationally less effort than military intervention which would be require an estimated 100, 000 US troops (Miami Herald, 10 Feb 2019).   3. It appears then that Venezuela’s own security forces will be instrumental in sustaining, or bringing down, Maduro’s rule during 2019:  For the most part, security forces have been loyal to Maduro — and have been rewarded with pay rises and various other handouts for that loyalty. On January 23, following Guaidó’s announcement, high-level military personnel voiced their continued support of Maduro (CNN 24 Jan 2019). But, with Guaidó promising amnesty to military members and politicians who defect, this loyalty may waver in the future. Already, up to 600 lower-ranking soldiers have been abandoning their posts. On January 21, a military revolt was suppressed by the government (Irish Times 23 Feb 2019; BBC 23 Feb 2019). This indicates the probability of a military overthrow is increasing. However, it is highly unlikely this will occur in the coming weeks given that the majority of security forces remain publicly loyal to Maduro, ruling out the option that Maduro will cease to be president before April 1. Based on historic data on coup and coup attempts though, the longer Maduro remains in power, the greater the likelihood of a military takeover. Right now, Venezuelan GDP per capita — an influential factor in inciting previous coups to date — is comparatively higher than countries that have previously experienced an attempt (its own 2002 attempt included). This, paired with the factors already mentioned — particularly current military support — indicate that a successful coup is unlikely to occur this year. But the likelihood increases the with each month that passes; where, ‘Maduro’s biggest vulnerability is the prospect of further economic decline’ (The Conversation 31 January 2019). While an overthrow of Maduro is likely before the next election, it is considered most probable that this will occur after January 1, 2020 — in that international intervention has been argued as unlikely, more time is needed for the situation in Venezuela to worsen to the point that military member and politicians are willing to defect and remove the president by force.

A limited list of product tanker operators willing to move refined product cargoes to Venezuela are commanding premium rates to supply the country from non-US sources. US sanctions in late January against Venezuela's state owned PdV, allied with Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, have halted US-Venezuela gasoline and naphtha movements and caused PdV to secure supply from alternate sources, particularly Europe, to plug the gap. But the transportation costs of getting those cargoes to Venezuela are coming at premiums. Shipowners face a host of potential problems that come with taking oil cargoes to Venezuela, including the risk of violating evolving US sanctions, infrastructure malfunction at Venezuelan ports, vessel seizure, and crime at Venezuelan ports. At least one major product tanker owner has stopped including Venezuela as a discharge option for its fixtures. For some shipowners the risk is worth it. Danish shipping firm Torm has leased out at least two of its medium range (MR) tankers to carry refined products, likely gasoline or naphtha, to Venezuela for Spanish oil company Repsol.
