José Alías Torres, general secretary of the CTV, spoke on the program La Tarde de NTN24 on the announcement of the interim president of Venezuela, Juan Guaidó, of a staggered strike in the public sector. Torres explained that "we have decided to radicalize the protests and from today we start to talk and tomorrow we will have a meeting in the National Assembly (...) because we will refine more concrete actions". Although they do not have a specific plan yet, because this will begin to be discussed from this Wednesday, he said that "it can be a full day, two or three days until other sectors join the protest and at a certain moment that will be irrepressible if there is no definitive answer. " These protests arise because of the low salaries as well as the attack that, they say, have suffered some public sector workers in the country who do not agree with the policies of Nicolás Maduro.

The forecast at hand identifies two main drivers, crucial for the future of the Venezuelan Maduro regime: The positioning of the military, as well as the impact of the US sanctions and the role of the international community. US sanctions and the role of the international community: While more than 50 countries accepted Guaido as Venezuela’s interim president, most of them ruled out a military intervention, such as the Lima Group states or the European ones (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-47436804). The US that explicitly did leave the option to intervene open, has with Elliot Abrams a special representative and hardliner on the top with experience in interventions in Latin America (during the Cold War) (https://www.cbsnews.com/news/ilhan-omar-elliott-abrams-venezuela-envoy-clash-over-us-meddling-in-latin-america/). However, they will most likely not intervene militarily due to the high risks aligned with a military operation. The same holds true for Russia. However, on 01/03 the US imposed additional visa restrictions and sanctions against Venezuelan officials and militaries (https://edition.cnn.com/2019/03/01/politics/abrams-us-venezuela-sanctions/index.html). These are only the latest in a series of sanctions by the US. In particular, the sanctions announced by the Treasury Department on 28/01 that prohibited US companies and individuals from doing business with Venezuela’s state-run oil company Pdvsa have potentially severe effects for the country and Maduro’s regime, because the oil exports to the US are Venezuela’s biggest source of incoming cash (oil exports to Russia and China mostly compensate for already existing debts) (https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/08/world/americas/venezuela-sanctions-maduro.html). After the announcement of the sanctions, export reduced by 40% within a week. Now the new American sanctions could cut Venezuela’s oil exports by two-thirds, to just $14 billion this year, and lead to a 26 percent reduction in the economy’s size (Ibid.). The idea behind the sanctions is to increase people’s suffering and promote even larger protests. They are also supposed to hit high level militaries and thereby motivate them to change sides (refer to military.) However, due to a strong illegal economy, that many of them benefit from, the central military leaders will most likely be able to survive the sanctions: “as we have learnt from Cuba, authoritarian regimes can be very resilient [against sanctions].” (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/feb/03/will-venezuela-oil-sanctions-be-the-silver-bullet-to-fell-maduro-regime) Another aspect that motivates the forecast at hand to assume a high probability of the Maduro regime to survive at least until 01/01/20, is the financial support of Russia. As a consequence of US sanctions, Russia’s state-run Rosneft has increased its output in Venezuela (Ibid.). Furthermore due to the nature of the global oil market, many analysts assume that Venezuela could find new markets in Asia, if it was willing to lower the price (https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/08/world/americas/venezuela-sanctions-maduro.html). These measurements could be sufficient to hold Maduro in power. Next to financial support from Russia, Venezuela can furthermore rely upon political support of Russia and China, e.g. in the UN. On 01/03 both members of the security council rejected a US resolution, demanding presidential elections (https://www.dw.com/en/venezuela-us-resolution-vetoed-by-russia-china-at-un-security-council/a-47734238).  Military: The military is the most important pillar of the Maduro regime, alongside the party's mass organizations and public sector workers; In particular, due to the low probability of a military intervention of foreign forces that would enforce the claim of self-appointed interim president Guaido (refer to impact on US sanctions). Without external support Guaido is dependent on the support of the Venezuelan military. While he managed to mobilize the masses with many former Maduro supporters changing sides (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/feb/10/venezuela-maduro-chavez-guaido-protests), the regime managed so far to prevail their influence over the military. This got particular clear, when the military blocked the entry of humanitarian aid into the country in February (https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/21/world/americas/venezuela-aid-block-brazil.html?module=inline). As a consequence, Guaido and the opposition reached a dead end after the failed attempt to break the blockade that got stylized as a „shutdown“ and the „end of Maduro.“ In the end, the humanitarian corridor did not open; instead, after the failed coup, the borders were closed and numerous opposition politicians were stuck in Colombia - including Guaido himself. The influence of Maduro over the military is so strong due to the diversity of groups that belong and profit from the military. Thus the military is not just a single professional vertical organization that can gained over by winning over the leading figures (https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/04/opinion/venezuela-military-maduro-guaido.html). Within this diverse groups reasons for the support of Maduro differ. Within the military high command many continue to believe in the ideology Maduro represents. Others enjoy big influence within the government and a huge range of benefits: leading ministerial posts for instance are filled by generals (https://www.swp-berlin.org/kurz-gesagt/2019/endspiel-in-venezuela/); Many others are engaged in lucrative illicit activities, such as drug trafficking (https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/theworldpost/wp/2019/02/07/venezuela-military/?utm_term=.72cc0f83e4b5). All of these leading groups in the military can’t be interested in a regime change, since the probability is very high that this would mean a loss of power and money for them. This holds also true despite Guaido’s promises of amnesty. This might be convincing the ordinary soldiers - that also experience the same poverty and humanitarian crisis as the rest of the population - but it is considered as highly unlikely that this would lead to a mass exodus.  Based upon these two drivers the forecast at hand estimates the probability of Maduro to cease before 01/04/19 and between 01/04/19 and 30/06/19 as rather low, each as of 15%. However, the chances for this event to materialize are still perceived higher as between 01/07/19 and 30/09/19, as well as between 01/10/19-31/12/19 , each attributed with a 5% probability. This is due to the attention the Venezuelan opposition enjoys at the moment in the international community as well as the perception of a change being possible, both internationally and within the Venezuelan population. Guaido’s return to Venezuela for instance were accompanied by many Western ambassadors, wich might have prevented Maduro from arresting him right away and stealing the opposition’s leader and biggest threat to him (https://lex18.com/news/2019/03/04/the-latest-anti-maduro-protesters-gather-in-venezuela/). This support might motivate the population further, in particular in combination with the sanctions and the amnesty that might lead low level soldiers to change sides. However, when the interest of the international community will move on to the next crises in the world, and an overlong stalement will realize, Guaido will most likely lose the support of the masses, aligned with a further willingness from militaries to change sides. That is why, the paper at hand estimates the likelihood of Maduro to stay in power at least until 01/01/20 as the most likely scenario with a probability of 60%.

Since the self-proclaimed assumption of the interim presidency of Venezuela on 23 January by Juan Guaidó and despite its recognition by more than 50 governments, Maduro’s control over the military and security forces remained largely intact - no regime governors or field generals had switched allegiances. For this reason, I assess that there is only a very little chance (2%) that Maduro will be overturned before April 21, which is in less than one month. In order to have such an outcome, it would be necessary an International intervention. In this regard, Although Trump recently stated that a military option for Venezuela was "not off the table”, before to play the military card the U.S.A would have to face a strong debate, both at the internal and international level. Indeed, the reputation of American interventionism has been strongly affected by the inconclusive and controversial external actions undertaken in recent years (e.g. Iraqi invasion). For this reason, at the internal level, before to intervein Trump would have to convince the parliament that it won’t be the umpteenth huge financial loss without any final benefit in return. At the external level, the Trump’s administration would have to convince the international community that is not another “American attempt of imperialism in the name of democracy” as over the years has been increasingly argued. Furthermore, on a side note, in order to legally legitimize such intervention, a motion should pass in the UN Security Council, where the Russian Federation detain (and is likely to use) the veto power. Yet, there is still the “Uniting for peace” motion (a formula which permits the UN General Assembly to allow a humanitarian intervention in case of an impasse in the Security Council), however it has rarely been used since the born of the United Nation. Therefore, the actual likelihood of American intervention, at least in the short term, is basically low. A fortiori since Russia is defending Nicolas Maduro‘s claim to the presidency in Venezuela and has strong interests in the region. What is more probable is that both Russia and the USA will indirectly sustain the two factions engaging a sort of new proxy War. However, even if such an outcome unfolded, it would require a long and bloody process before a radical political change happens (as it is the case of Assad in Syria who, despite 8 years of civil and proxy war, still holds the power).  For the reasons above, I consider the most likely scenario Maduro being still in power in January 2020, which I have assessed with a 60% chance. That said, other possible scenarios must be taken into consideration. As Daniel Lansberg-Rodríguez (2019) noted, “the more atrocities Venezuela’s dictator commits, the less likely his regime is to survive him”. In this regard, the recent Maduro’s refusal of humanitarian aids from USA (240 tons of medicines and food), considering them a sort of Trojan horse and accusing the US of interference in internal affairs and closing the relations with Colombia and Brazil, it is everything but beneficial for Maduro’s popularity and legitimation. The diplomatic isolation and the worsening of the internal humanitarian conditions (although considered by Maduro the consequence of the infamous American sanctions) might lead the military and security forces to shift side or to independently claim the power. Without military support, the end of the Maduro’s regime would unfold rapidly.  However, if it is hard to assess whether such a scenario will unfold or not, it is even harder to deem when it is more likely to happen. In this regard, I believe it as more likely between April and June 2019 (20% chance) since the debate over the future of Venezuela is vivid as never before and Guido’s symbolic act still fresh. The more time will pass, the more Venezuela risk to be stacked in an impasse similar to the Syrian one, lowering the chances of an overthrown of president Maduro.  Sources:

What it comes down to is that in order to drive Maduro from office, Guaido must have more resources than Maduro *within Venezuela*. This means Guaido's ostensible control of financial resources don't really mean anything unless he can translate that into the ability to bribe, convince, or coerce enough Venezuelans to accept his claim to the presidency. So, for example, the takeover of the Citgo board of directors means that Guaido has control of an office building in Houston. Maduro has control of soldiers with guns in Venezuela. This doesn't mean that things like the Citgo transfer are irrelevant; but there have to be a lot of intermediate steps that get you from "Guaido controls Citgo" to "Guaido controls Venezuela." Venezuela’s oil production—which accounts for 95% of the country’s export revenues—is but a shadow of its former glory days of 3 million barrels per day as it was in 1997. By 2017 its production had fallen to 2 million bpd, and by this time last year, Venezuela’s production had fallen again to 1.5 million bpd.  According to OPEC’s latest monthly oil market report, Venezuela’s production last month fell to 1.1 million bpd.
From: https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/Congressional-Hearing-This-Is-How-Far-Venezuelan-Oil-Production-Could-Fall.html The oil market is changing:
Quality matters, not quantity. That was the message from the International Energy Agency (IEA) in its latest Oil Market Report. The world has plenty of oil, but perhaps not the right type of oil. A series of events have caused the market for light oil to diverge from that of medium and heavier blends. This trend has been underway for some time, but the deviation has magnified recently, and could cause havoc as 2019 wears on. The backdrop is the surge in U.S. shale production. The multi-year boom in light sweet oil from Texas and North Dakota, among other places, has added huge volumes of light oil to global supply. The U.S. Gulf Coast, where much of this oil is heading, has not been able to keep up. Refiners are churning out as much as possible, which has led to a glut of gasoline. But excess barrels have been increasingly exported, adding huge volumes of light oil onto the global market. To accommodate steadily rising barrels of light oil, OPEC and its non-OPEC partners have backed out their own supplies in order to prevent a crash in prices. But many OPEC members produce medium and heavier blends. The quantity of global supply may not be vastly different, but the quality of the crude slate has changed dramatically.
From: https://oilprice.com/Energy/Crude-Oil/Emerging-Quality-Problem-To-Haunt-Oil-Markets.html

Hello fellow forecasters! This is my first go at GJP; it took me time to sit down and forge my thoughts into words. After two weeks spent on racking the internet for useful information about revolutions/coup d’etats and current situation in Venezuela, I came to terms with the fact that it is  hell of a job to form an accurate forecast. 
I began to untangle this conundrum by accepting a simple truth: firstly, it is exquisitely difficult to forecast future events without looking at a bigger picture. Secondly, none of us can be certain of the predicted results. One can be right but not necessarily reasonable. Having said that - let me lay out my reasoning around the unfolding events.  OUTSIDE VIEW 	Out of coup d’etats and revolution around the world, that happened since 2010, approximately one in five was successful.  INSIDE VIEW Factors against Maduro’s regime: INTERNAL  Guaido presents an united voice for the opposition claims 
Amnesty offered for every soldier who will desert Maduro’s army ranks
Declining economy, skyrocketing inflation, shortages of food and medicine 
Stretched poverty threshold, mounting dissatisfaction  
High percentage of urban population might lead to outburst of a revolution EXTERNAL The US, France, UK, Germany pressuring Maduro to hold new presidential elections, Maduro argues that they interfere with Venezuelan internal affairs and blackmail a sovereign country
The Bank of England freezes Venezuelan assets (gold) 
US no longer buys oil from Venezuelan stated-owned company; revenues constituted a huge part of state revenues; oil exported to other countries like China and Russia does not create a revenue, it is used to pay debts; the revenues might dwindle by more than 30%
Possible yet unlikely military intervention guided by the US 
Trump might try to score points engaging into a conflict in his backyard; might strike a geopolitical deal with Russia, promising not to mix with Russia’s backyard affairs if Russia commits to do the same Factors supporting Maduro’s regime: INTERNAL Military support from the army bribed with nationalized institutions
Political INERTIA of the current political setup  
Abundant spy-net inside the army counter rebellious attempts   
Strong political support in society despite the economic disaster, mostly due to the bolivarian heritage
Lack of confidence in the US-backed opposition government’s ability to install itself and grip the power strongly enough to maintain security in the country
FEAR of a civil war and bloodbath
Social media censorship and disturbances undermine opposition’s capabilities to organize a vehement campaign   EXTERNAL Only one in five Coup d’etat or Revolution in the last nine year has succeeded
Support from i.e. Russia, China, Iran, Mexico 
Russia and Cuba have allegedly dispatched an unit of trained merchants to guard Maduro Personally I find it difficult to attribute numerical importance to the above collection of notions. Although I have listed a strong representation of factors against Maduro’s regime (the collection undoubtedly is bigger than the pro-Maduro, as the media coverage tend to sway towards ousting the current president), I hypothesize that Maduro’s grip on the power will remain strong, continuously fueled the army, by the political inertia and society’s fear of bloodbath.  QUESTIONS to future-self: How old are the army’s generals? Would it be more likely for the to sway to the opposition’s side if the majority (<75%) were under 50? 
What is the relation between the size of the combined military and police forces span of control over the populations in the countries that have witnessed a successful rebellion against the countries where it failed? Urban population? 
How stern will be the consequences of the US embargo on Venezuelan society? How to measure it?

PUERTO ORDAZ, Venezuela (Reuters) - Venezuela’s Pemon, an indigenous people living along the border with Brazil, are determined to allow into the embattled country any foreign aid that may arrive, even if that means a showdown with Venezuelan security forces and the government of President Nicolas Maduro. .....
Six leaders of the Pemon community residing in the “Gran Sabana” (or “Great Savannah”) municipality bordering Brazil told Reuters that the population’s pressing needs should trump any politicization of humanitarian aid. The Gran Sabana, a grassy plain dotted with immense tabletop mountains in the southern state of Bolivar, is home to the only paved border crossing between Venezuela and Brazil. “We are physically prepared - without weapons - and willing to open the border to receive the humanitarian aid,” Gran Sabana Mayor Emilio Gonzalez told Reuters. “Neither the National Guard not the government can stop this.” Indigenous communities boast a greater degree of autonomy than others in Venezuela. "If this is a protracted supply shortfall," Croft told CNN Business, "the SPR will have diminishing returns in terms of effectiveness." American refineries will feel the unintended consequences of Trump's Venezuela crackdown The market for heavy crude is already tight. Heavier barrels, such as the Maya grade from Mexico, are typically cheaper than West Texas Intermediate, the US benchmark. But that relationship has flipped.
"This is very unusual and shows just how much the world (and US refiners) need heavier grades of crude," Pavel Molchanov, energy analyst at Raymond James, wrote to clients this week. What about Saudi Arabia?
The problem is that the ideal sources for heavy crude are sidelined.
Mexico, for instance, is facing structural production declines that will take "months if not years to reverse," Fitzmaurice said.
Canada is running out of pipelines to get its thick oil to the US Gulf Coast. Rail is too expensive to ship Canadian crude.
And then there's Saudi Arabia.
US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin hinted that refiners could turn to Saudi Arabia for heavy crude. "I'm sure many of our friends in the Middle East will be happy to make up the supply," Mnuchin said late last month when announcing the PDVSA sanctions.

The oil market became oversupplied, and prices plummeted. Saudi Arabia has since slashed output in a bid to stabilize prices.

The spread between Brent futures and Dubai swaps averaged $2.58/b in Q3 of 2018, according to Platts data. The same spread narrowed to $1.86/b over Q4, and has narrowed even further to $1.16/b to date in January. A narrow Brent/Dubai EFS spread implies that medium to heavy sour Dubai-linked crude grades are getting relatively pricier compared to lighter, sweeter Brent-linked crude grades. The spread dipped to 99 cents/b as of 0300 GMT during Asian trading hours on Wednesday.

While this is this going to have the biggest impact on fuel oil and middle distillates, it is also going to influence the crude flows of heavy sweet barrels. In fact, it already is. The Cuban regime, says Romero, wants to avoid three "worst-case scenarios", which have in the past led to the downfall of governments sympathetic to Havana. The first was the overthrow of Chile's President Salvador Allende in 1973. This explains its efforts to placate the Venezuelan military. The national guard, which has been in the frontline quelling demonstrations, has been awarded bonuses for its good offices. The second case was Grenada in 1983, where Cuban influence was undermined by the regime's mistakes, prior to invasion by American troops. Havana is consequently determined to shore up Maduro's authority and end the dispute with his rival, Captain Diosdado Cabello, who is head of the National Assembly and deputy leader. The third scenario to avoid is an election in the throes of an economic crisis, as occurred in Nicaragua in 1990. So the priority in Venezuela is to stop inflation and end the shortages that are sapping popular support for the Chavistas. An election is due next year. Havana is clearly keen to maintain the status quo. But killing demonstrators, imprisoning political opponents and members of parliament – making martyrs of them in the process – is a far cry from the low-intensity repression that Raúl Castro has inflicted on Cuban dissidents since he took over from his brother Fidel. Nor is Cuba in the habit of engaging in dialogue with the opposition, as Maduro did on 10 April, broadcast live on television.

This kind of reminds me of the early days of the Arab Spring, specifically the demonstrations against Assad. In that case, we also had some high-ranking generals defecting to the opposition, but significantly, they didn't seem to be able to persuade their troops to follow them. So like Syria, massive demonstrations by civilians and defections of high-level officers may not be enough to oust a president who is determined to stay in power. Unlike Assad, however, Maduro has to deal with the danger of direct and forceful US. intervention. It's hard to believe that the U.S, would stand aside during a full-scale civil war in a South American country. Other countries in the region would probably be willing to contribute token forces to give the intervention and "international" character. However, Maduro might be able to get away with a low level of violence - just enough to intimidate the opposition, but not enough to seem too egregious. So we might see live ammunition used against demonstrators, then a court-martial of some scapegoat colonel or major who will in the end be allowed to retire without any real criminal penalty and a nice pension. We'll see. From what I know, there have so far been no fatalities in the demonstrations - that is, no conspicuous fatalities that have drawn international attention. I'm sure there have been fatalities in a variety of incidents associated with the unrest in Venezuela. However, once there are fatalities that are directly blamed on Maduro, the more likely it is that he will attempt to cling to power at all costs. The reason for this is that there will almost certainly be calls for him to be put on trial to answer for any deaths that his troops cause. So there will be no place that can actually guarantee him asylum; he will be considered an international outlaw. So for him to flee and accept an offer of asylum is a taking a real chance - he can be handed over at any time, and used as a bargaining chip by his host country. He would only take such a deal if he had absolutely no choice, and if he thinks he can fight it out with his opponents, he will. If Maduro isn't gone by April, he may be in power for a long time.

https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/28/us/politics/venezuela-sanctions-trump-oil.html?emc=edit_mbe_20190129&nl=morning-briefing-europe&nlid=7782502520190129&te=1 Jan. 28, 2019  The Trump administration imposed sanctions against Venezuela’s state-owned oil company on Monday, seeking to cripple the government of embattled President Nicolás Maduro by cutting off its main source of cash. The move marked the first punitive step by the United States to force Mr. Maduro to give up power since the opposition leader, Juan Guaidó, declared himself interim president .  . . . . .  Administration officials said the financial penalties are expected to block $7 billion in assets and result in $11 billion in export losses over the next year for Venezuela’s government, starving it from its most important source of revenue and foreign currency.
. . . 
In an interview Monday before the sanctions were announced, Mr. Guaidó said his nascent government was making every effort it could to get control of Venezuela’s international assets — and mainly the state oil company.
. . . Mr. Guaidó said the National Assembly estimated that $30 billion had gone missing from the oil company in recent years.
. . . 
Sanctions on Pdvsa potentially put at risk as much as a half-million barrels of oil that the United States imports from Venezuela, representing roughly 3 percent of American demand. The United States also exports roughly 100,000 barrels of light oil to Venezuela daily; it is used for blending so heavy oil can be transported through pipelines to refineries and export terminals. Purchases of Venezuelan oil by American companies would be released once Pdvsa is controlled by a government led by Mr. Guaidó, officials said. Generally, American citizens will be barred from engaging in transactions with the company, although the Treasury Department said it would issue licenses to permit certain transactions and activities within specific time periods. Mr. Mnuchin said refineries in the United States could continue to process the oil, and Venezuelan oil that is already at sea could continue to its destination. Additionally, he said, the Treasury Department has issued licenses to some European and Caribbean countries so they can make a proper transition as the sanctions take effect. Pdvsa’s American subsidiary Citgo, which operates three refineries, sends Venezuela gasoline and other refined petroleum products. Under the sanctions, Citgo will be allowed to continue operating, and any money it would send to Pdvsa will go into a designated account, Mr. Mnuchin said.
. . . 
Risa Grais-Targow, an analyst of Latin American affairs at Eurasia Group, said it appeared that Pdvsa could no longer export oil to American refineries. That would force the company to sell to Asian markets at a steep discount, she said. “It looks like a de facto embargo because Venezuela will not sell to the U.S. if it cannot collect the revenues,” she said. Russ Dallen, the managing partner of Caracas Capital Markets, who specializes in the oil industry, said the United States could put money owed to Pdvsa in an account controlled by the National Assembly. Both Russia and China receive large oil shipments from Venezuela as payments of debt held by the global powers. They do not pay for the oil in cash. That has meant the half-million barrels sent to the United States daily has been a critical source of revenue and foreign currency for Mr. Maduro’s government. “U.S. oil exports are where Venezuela gets its cash flow,” Mr. Dallen said. Any problems in that cash flow could jeopardize Citgo. In August, an American judge declared that Crystallex, a Canadian gold company whose assets were seized in a 2008 nationalization move by Hugo Chávez, the Venezuelan president at the time, could seize Citgo assets as part of a repayment scheme. In an effort to keep control of the refinery operations, Mr. Maduro’s government has used what little money it still has to pay off part of the $1.4 billion judgment. If Venezuela stops payments, Mr. Maduro could lose control of Citgo, Mr. Dallen said. Mr. Maduro seemed aware of what was at stake. “With this measure they’re setting out to steal the Citgo company from all Venezuelans,” he said at the diplomatic ceremony in Caracas. “No, Donald Trump. No, no, no.” Francisco J. Monaldi, a Venezuelan oil expert at Rice University in Texas, compared the sanctions to a “nuclear bomb.” But he said the moves appeared aimed not at crippling the Venezuelan oil company, but blocking Mr. Maduro’s access to the revenue. For example, the sanctions included exceptions to allow the American oil company Chevron, along with Halliburton and Schlumberger, two large oil services providers, to continue working in Venezuela. Mr. Mnuchin said he did not expect the sanctions to affect American gas prices. “There has been excess oil,” he said. “Many of our friends in the Middle East will be happy to make up the supply.” The Trump administration has been urging fellow members of the Organization of American States to recognize Mr. Guaidó as Venezuela’s president, and has promised $20 million in food and medical aid to ease economic pain for the country’s citizens. That money would presumably only go to Mr. Guaidó’s government. The Venezuelan economy has collapsed under the policies by Mr. Maduro’s leftist, authoritarian government, and three million Venezuelans have fled their homeland. Colombia alone has taken in at least one million refugees.
. . . 
Administration officials indicated that Mr. Trump was still not ruling out military intervention in his efforts to pressure Mr. Maduro to step down. “The president has made it very clear on this matter that all options are on the table,” John R. Bolton, the national security adviser, told reporters while clutching a yellow notepad with a cryptic phrase scrawled on top: “5,000 troops to Colombia.”

Venezuela's self-proclaimed president Juan Guaido yesterday called for two new protests, in an effort to push the military to turn against leader Nicolas Maduro and back a European ultimatum demanding free elections within the week. The head of the opposition-controlled National Assembly said the first of the nationwide strikes, on Wednesday from noon to 2pm, would be one "to demand that the armed forces side with the people." The second, on Saturday, will be a "big national and international rally to back the support of the EU and the ultimatum" that they would recognize Guaido as interim president unless Maduro calls elections by February 3. The U.S. separately warned there would be a "significant response" if U.S. diplomats, Guaido or the National Assembly were targeted with violence and intimidation. Maduro so far has not budged from his position, telling CNN Turk: "No one can give us an ultimatum."

Juan Guaidó, recognised as Venezuela’s interim president by all the major democracies in the Americas apart from Mexico, plans a series of gatherings to consolidate his parallel government. A big demonstration is expected against the regime of Nicolás Maduro, who claims to retain the presidency, after rigging an election last year—and who controls the army and much of government. Mr Maduro’s propaganda machine has been flat-footed in its response to the threat posed by Mr Guaidó. The 35-year-old proclaimed himself president last week, on the basis that Mr Maduro is illegitimate and the head of the national assembly must step in if the presidency is vacant. Mr Maduro initially tried to belittle his rival as “that little boy”. He has since said he is prepared to meet him. On January 26th Mr Maduro delayed by a month his ultimatum that American diplomats must leave the country. Officials in Washington say they do not take orders from “the former President”.

The Netherlands, Germany, France, Spain and Britain are pressing  Maduro to hold new elections within eight days, saying they will recognize Guaidó as the interim president otherwise. Maduro has  backed down from demanding that all American diplomats leave the country, and his government has refrained from detaining Mr. Guaidó.   I doubt that this is out of a respect for the rule of law; I assume it is based on practical concerns and Maduro's recognition of the limits of his power. As soon as the sycophants surrounding Mugabe saw that Mnangagwa could offer them something more (more power, wealth, safety), Mugabe was utterly and literally abandoned overnight.   Maduro is not Chavez.  Chavez was beloved.  Maduro is considered a clown.  Maduro is an embarrassment.  He insisted on doing things on live tv to make himself appear macho (a la Putin), but invariably botched them up:  falling off a bicycle on live tv, for example.  He has run the country into the ground, and Venezuelans realize it.  Venezuelans,  even those who have profited from him,  will abandon Maduro even more rapidly than Zimbabweans abandoned Mugabe. Literally millions of Venezuelans have fled to neighboring nations and are eager to return home.  Before I started forecasting on this question, I read an article about Venezuelans in exile starting to organize to support Guaido and return. April 1st is 9 weeks away. MOSCOW - Venezuela and President Nicolas Maduro have been a costly investment for Russia and China as they seek to expand their influence in Latin America. They are determined now not to lose ground. Moscow and Beijing are warily eyeing the events in Venezuela last week, when opposition leader Juan Guaido declared himself acting president and demanded that Maduro resign. The United States and other nations recognized Guaido as the rightful president. Maduro, a pariah in many world capitals, has been a frequent guest of Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese President Xi Jinping. With every visit, Maduro walked away with new loans and cash. In the 10 years ending in 2016, China lent Venezuela about $62 billion, much of which Caracas could repay with oil. Moscow in the last several years gave Venezuela $17 billion in loans and investment, and in December the two governments signed a new deal in which Russia will invest $6 billion in Venezuela's oil and gold sectors. China and Russia are Venezuela's two main creditors, and they have been the principal economic force keeping the Maduro government afloat, making the difference between solvency and bankruptcy, financial experts say. But the two powerful nations have different attitudes toward their financial relationship with the crumbling socialist South American nation. China is more pragmatic; Russia is more ideological... Good synopsis from the Economist this morning:
Venezuelans are waking up to their first full day under two presidents. The one with the guns is Nicolás Maduro, whose disastrous regime has pauperised the country and who won a second term in a rigged election held last year. The one with the legitimacy is Juan Guaidó, a 35-year-old politician chosen as head of the country’s national assembly earlier this month, who on January 23rd declared himself acting president. Mr Guaidó was swiftly recognised by other countries: President Donald Trump was the first to endorse him; Canada and all the major economies in South America followed. Growing protests are evidence that Mr Guaidó also has the backing of most Venezuelans, even those from the poorest neighbourhoods of Caracas, where hunger and anger have overcome the fear of the regime. But Mr Guaidó cannot yet claim to have the support of the army. It will ultimately decide which president prevails.

Barring some unforeseen events, Maduro will probably stay in power for the foreseeable future. The military seems to be overwhelmingly loyal as multiple coup attempts (or false flags?) have been unsuccessful. Nevertheless, he remains very unpopular and if conditions worsen - which they are likely to do - he might face a more significant threat to his rule than the previous significant protests.

Maduro has faced 3 coups attempts already, and it was reported in September 2018 that the Trump administration had been talking to military officers about a potential coup (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/sep/08/trump-nicolas-maduro-overthrow-venezuelan-meetings). Dictators are generally quite good at keeping power as long as they can spread benefits to allies who help them maintain their power, so Maduro has to keep his allies rolling in the cash from oil, drugs and other illicit activities, but the danger for him is the people who are excluded from this in the military. But they face enormous challenges even if a potential coup succeeds, which may well dissuade them from doing it. (restoring order, fixing the economy, getting control of assets like oil production, dealing with Russia, China and the US as well as people who are about to lose out from the status quo). I think he is likely to survive given all of that. I don't think that he will be pushed out by protestors even with things as bad as they are - so many people have fled the country that protests have gone down, and the opposition do not seem to be in a fit state to take over even if he was forced out. I also think that he would be quite willing to crack down using the military on any serious opposition. The new presidential period however does start on Jan 10th, and that could generate protests. He doesn't as far as I know have any health issues, so I have it that less than 1% that he dies this year in office, like his predecessor did.

Maduro seems secure. The only real risk now is a military coup but that seems unlikely given the extensive privileges the military has and the presence of Cuban and other spies monitoring soldiers' loyalty. If anything the people pouring out of the country make Maduro more secure since many of the people leaving are presumably opposed to him.

For as bad as his countries problems are, his people are choosing exit over voice in such numbers that it make his violent end, (voice in extremis) less likely.
Stricter immigration limits in the region would change this, however.

At this point I see that Maduro dies as the major contributor to the probability of him ceasing to be president. At 56 years old, a life insurer would see about 0.85% risk of death from now until 2020. I would say Maduro's risk is maybe 5 times that, plus a slim chance that he could cease to be president due to political opposition. There is no saying when that might happen, so spreading evenly across 2019, and the remaining probability goes to 2020 and beyond.
Cratering oil prices will make him step aside for "health" before a coup may happen.
